text.#text: Congress finds the following:
The volume of crude oil transported by rail has significantly increased from—
21,000 barrels a day in 2009 to 1.1 million barrels a day in 2014; and
9,500 rail-carloads in 2008 to 415,000 rail-carloads in 2013.

At any given time, more than 2.5 million gallons of crude oil is being transported across the
			 country to refineries totaling a distance of more than 1000 miles.
More oil was spilled in 2013 from freight traffic than in the previous 4 decades combined.

Increased spills result in catastrophes that have significantly and adversely impacted the
			 following communities:
Minnesota, in March 2013, when 30,000 gallons of crude oil spilled because of derailed cars.

Lac-Mégantic, Canada, in July 2013, when 1.6 million gallons of crude oil spilled, igniting a fire
			 and exploding, killing 47 people and forcing 2,000 people from their
			 homes.

North Dakota, in December 2013, when 400,000 million gallons of crude oil spilled, igniting a fire
			 and forcing 65 percent of residents from their homes.

Virginia, in March 2014, when thousands of gallons of oil spilled, contaminating the James River
			 and requiring the evacuation of 78,000 people in the downtown of the city.
